instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.P3V3SUS_EN: What is P3V3SUS_EN? P3V3SUS_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_SUS power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Hello. Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board here with no power. It had little corrosion around <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>, so I removed the IC, cleaned everything and replaced the IC. Still no power. I get a little low voltage on <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>. It should be 3.42V but I get only 2.9~3V. Replaced the IC a lot of times already and same result. If I inject 3.4V on <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> pads the board starts, but obviously this isn't a solution. Already lifted all caps on the line but same result. Any ideas on where to look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
yes, it gets steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but does not output correct voltage. That's why I thought <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> was bad initially, forgot to mention.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Looks like bad <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>.
Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Diode Mode on <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0.392
Already replaced about 10 times <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Brunomotter,

had recently an issue with <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, which is also the same load switch. Remove <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> and inspect closely in what state are the pins on the board. It is possible that pad for enable signal is damaged and that EN voltage is not really getting to the switch. Both Vin and Vout have double pads/pins but EN is only one pad and very sensitive. It is possible that EN signal doesn't have a real contact to the witch ball, since it is BGA chip.
If pad on the board is even slightly damaged, then it is possible that there is no contact between EN ball on the TPS chip and actual pad on the motherboard.

There is also one more thing you can check. When measuring voltage, place red probe on the casing of the <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> switch and check wheter there is voltage on the case to the ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Thanks for answering and trying to help. Removed <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> and enable signal is steady 3.3V on the pad, so no problem there. I tried jumping 3.3V directly to <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> and when doing this 3.3V line goes to 3V as when with <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> in place. Something is dragging down the line and I cannot figure out what is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Replaced once again <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> and for precaution <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, same result!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Disconnect anything, keep only 5 pins power cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Yes, that's how it is right now. Same thing. Tested with known good magsafe board and cable and with known good magsafe board with no interconnect cable. Same results.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: I don't have any other ideas... Already poked around everywhere on this board. Any other suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> drops when solder <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>?
Did you solder it in correct way?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Yes, properly soldered, I removed from identical donor board and soldered in same orientation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: And it's not <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> that gets dragged down. It's just not outputting correct voltage. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is low. Should be 3.3 and is 3.08V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Does the board start if you bypass <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>?
Just for test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: I tried bypassing, jumping 3v3 directly. The board starts for some times then stops. When I jump <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> directly to the output it drags <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> down to 3.08V. If I solder the MOSFET the <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is fine but the output stays on 3.08V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Doesn't try to start with 3V at <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: If I inject 3.3V from bench PSU the board starts, but if I make a jumper from any 3.3V line from the board it will drag that line down and intermittently start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Looks like a cap leaking voltage, but I lifted literally every single cap on the line and problem was not solved.
